content: The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2005" provides interim protections for the Social Security Trust Fund surplus. The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2005" establishes a Social Security Surplus Protection Account in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to transfer social security surplus amounts after each fiscal year. The "Savings for Seniors Act of 2005" creates a Social Security Surplus Protection Account in the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to transfer surplus amounts based on tax revenues reported to the Treasury Secretary. The text discusses the calculation of taxes on self-employment income reported to the Treasury Secretary under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes the applicable tax rate, deductions, and adjustments to tax liabilities under chapter 1. The text discusses tax liabilities under chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to payments from the Trust Fund, with restrictions on investment by the Managing Trustee for the Account balance. The text discusses tax liabilities under chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to payments from the Trust Fund, with restrictions on investment by the Managing Trustee for the Account balance. A provision of Federal law authorizes an investment vehicle other than US obligations, resulting in the transfer of Trust Fund assets to the Treasury's general fund. SEC. 3. SOCIAL SECURITY INVESTMENT COMMISSION. Established in the executive branch is a Social Security Investment Commission to study and recommend effective investment vehicles for the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission will submit a report with recommendations by October 1, 2007. The Social Security Investment Commission is composed of 9 members appointed by various officials, with expertise in financial investments and pension benefit plans. Members serve for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Social Security Investment Commission is composed of 9 members appointed by officials with financial expertise. Members serve for the life of the Commission and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission administers the program, establishes investment policies for the Savings Fund, and ensures prudent investments for retirement income. The Social Security Investment Commission oversees funds for retirement income, reviews investment performance, manages social security savings annuities, approves the budget, and complies with fiduciary responsibilities. Meetings are held to discuss these matters. The Commission meets monthly and can convene additional meetings as needed. Three members constitute a quorum for decision-making. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's authority. Members receive compensation. The Commission members are compensated at the daily rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule and are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report.
